verses.text: When they came near to Jerusalem, to Bethphage and Bethany at the Mount of Olives, Jesus sent two of his disciples,
verses.comment: This verse marks the beginning of Jesus' final entry into Jerusalem, fulfilling prophetic anticipation about the Messiah's approach to Jerusalem. See Zech. 9:9.

verses.text: and said to them, 'Go into the village ahead of you. As soon as you enter it, you will find a colt tied there, which no one has ever ridden. Untie it and bring it here.'
verses.comment: The colt that has never been ridden is a symbol of sacred use, pointing to messianic fulfillment. Jesus’ foreknowledge here subtly reveals His divine authority.

verses.text: If anyone asks you, 'Why are you doing this?' say, 'The Lord needs it and will send it back here immediately.'
verses.comment: Jesus refers to Himself as 'the Lord', asserting His authority. This is a subtle claim to divinity (see Ps. 110:1; 'The Lord says to my Lord').

verses.text: So they went and found a colt outside in the street, tied at a doorway. They untied it.
verses.comment: The disciples' obedience points to the necessity of following Jesus’ instructions fully and exactly—a model for all faithful Christians.

verses.text: Some people standing there asked, 'What are you doing, untying the colt?'
verses.comment: The question from bystanders provides a narrative setting for Jesus’ demonstration of sovereignty.

verses.text: They answered them just as Jesus had told them, and they let them go.
verses.comment: Obedience to Jesus leads to favor and success, a repeated theme throughout Scripture (see 1 Sam. 15:22).

verses.text: They brought the colt to Jesus, threw their cloaks over it, and He sat on it.
verses.comment: Cloaks laid on the colt symbolize royal honor and recognition of Jesus as King, fulfilling prophecy about the Messiah.

verses.text: Many people spread their cloaks on the road, while others spread leafy branches they had cut from the fields.
verses.comment: The spreading of cloaks and branches points to the reception of a king, an echo of Solomon's enthronement (1 Kings 1:38-40) and a prefigurement of Christ’s kingship.

verses.text: Those who went ahead and those who followed shouted, 'Hosanna! Blessed is He who comes in the name of the Lord!'
verses.comment: 'Hosanna' is a plea for salvation but had become a term of praise. Psalm 118 is a Messianic psalm, affirming Jesus as the awaited Savior.

verses.text: 'Blessed is the coming kingdom of our father David! Hosanna in the highest!'
verses.comment: The crowd connects Jesus with the Davidic promise and Messianic expectations (2 Sam 7). This is a public endorsement of Christ's kingly mission.

verses.text: Jesus entered Jerusalem and went into the temple. After looking around at everything, since it was already late, He went out to Bethany with the twelve.
verses.comment: Jesus' inspection of the temple foreshadows His later decisive actions there, indicating His concern for true worship and the spiritual health of God's people.

verses.text: The next day, as they were leaving Bethany, He was hungry.
verses.comment: Jesus’ hunger reveals His true humanity, a core Christian doctrine about the Incarnation.

verses.text: Seeing in the distance a fig tree in leaf, He went to find out if it had any fruit. When He came to it, He found nothing but leaves, because it was not the season for figs.
verses.comment: The fig tree often symbolizes Israel in prophetic writings. The lack of fruit signifies spiritual barrenness (Hos. 9:10).

verses.text: Then He said to it, 'May no one ever eat fruit from you again.' And His disciples heard Him say it.
verses.comment: Jesus curses the fig tree as a prophetic sign against fruitlessness, a judgment motif throughout the Old Testament (see Jer. 8:13).

verses.text: When they came to Jerusalem, Jesus entered the temple, and began to drive out those who were selling and those buying in the temple. He overturned the tables of the money changers and the seats of those who sold doves.
verses.comment: Jesus purifies the temple, fulfilling Mal. 3:1-3. The cleansing of the temple points to Christ's authority over worship, highlighting the holiness demanded in God's house.

verses.text: He would not allow anyone to carry goods through the temple.
verses.comment: This prohibition on trading signifies the complete set-apartness of the temple. True worship is free from distraction and profane use.

verses.text: He was teaching them, and said, 'Is it not written: My house will be called a house of prayer for all nations? But you have made it a den of robbers.'
verses.comment: Jesus combines quotations from Isaiah and Jeremiah, teaching with divine authority. The reference to 'all nations' foreshadows the universal call to worship (see Isa. 2:2).

verses.text: The chief priests and the scribes heard this and began looking for a way to destroy Him, for they were afraid of Him, because the whole crowd was amazed at His teaching.
verses.comment: Opposition from the religious authorities intensifies, showing a conflict between earthly power and Jesus’ spiritual authority.

verses.text: Every evening Jesus and His disciples would leave the city.
verses.comment: This detail shows Jesus’ withdrawal, likely for prayer and preparation—a reminder of the value of devotion outside of busy places.

verses.text: In the morning, as they passed by, they saw the fig tree withered from the roots.
verses.comment: The sudden withering of the fig tree is a visible sign of the consequences of spiritual barrenness. The roots being withered indicates judgment at the very source.

verses.text: Peter remembered and said to Him, 'Rabbi, look! The fig tree You cursed has withered.'
verses.comment: Peter’s recognition stresses Jesus’ miraculous power and authority over creation, confirming His divinity.

verses.text: Jesus replied to them, 'Have faith in God.'
verses.comment: Jesus emphasizes faith as the foundation for spiritual life. Complete reliance on God brings about miraculous results.

verses.text: Truly I tell you, whoever says to this mountain, 'Be taken up and thrown into the sea,' and does not doubt in his heart but believes that what he says will happen, it will be done for him.
verses.comment: This hyperbole about moving mountains highlights the extraordinary power of unwavering faith, reiterating Old Testament themes (Zech. 4:7).

verses.text: For this reason I tell you, whatever you ask in prayer, believe that you have received it, and it will be yours.
verses.comment: Prayer is effective when approached with trusting faith. This verse has been cherished for fostering devotion and reliance on God.

verses.text: And whenever you stand praying, forgive, if you have anything against anyone, so that your Father who is in heaven may forgive you your trespasses.
verses.comment: Forgiveness is directly connected to receiving God’s forgiveness. The vertical and horizontal aspects of reconciliation are united in Christian worship (see the Lord’s Prayer).

verses.text: [But if you do not forgive, neither will your Father in heaven forgive your trespasses.]
verses.comment: This verse is omitted in some early manuscripts, but reinforces the seriousness of forgiving others—a teaching central to Jesus’ moral instruction.

verses.text: They came again to Jerusalem. As He was walking in the temple, the chief priests, the scribes, and the elders came to Him
verses.comment: Another confrontation with the temple authorities, who represent the continuity of Israel’s religious leadership and Jesus’ fulfillment of its permanence.

verses.text: and said to Him, 'By what authority are You doing these things? Or who gave You this authority to do them?'
verses.comment: The leaders' questioning about authority points to a central theme: Jesus’ authoritative mission is of divine origin.

verses.text: Jesus said to them, 'I will ask you one question. Answer Me, and I will tell you by what authority I am doing these things.
verses.comment: Jesus responds with a question, exposing the hearts of His challengers. This teaching method draws attention to truth through dialogue.

verses.text: Was the baptism of John from heaven or from men? Answer Me.'
verses.comment: John’s baptism is intimately connected to Jesus’ identity and mission. The implication is that true authority is rooted in divine commissioning.

verses.text: They argued among themselves, 'If we say,
If we say, "From men"—they were afraid of the crowd, because everyone held that John really was a prophet.
verses.comment: The leaders’ fear of the people over the truth shows the danger of placing human opinion above God’s revelation.

verses.text: So they answered Jesus, 'We do not know.' And Jesus said to them, 'Neither will I tell you by what authority I am doing these things.'
verses.comment: The exchange reveals the hardness of heart among the religious authorities. Jesus withholds an explicit answer; His deeds and fulfillment of Scripture are themselves His testimony (see Isa. 35:5-6). This passage highlights the importance of spiritual authority handed down and recognized through divine revelation.
